PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.)

Name: Mrs. J. A. [illegible]
Address: [illegible]
Birthplace: Scottish

Where did you set up housekeeping? Sask. (N.W.T.)

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our province.

Name: Mrs. J. A. Munro

Address: 2 Balmer Road, Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Birthplace: Scotland

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start homesteading in Western Canada? (1894)

Where did you set up housekeeping? (Edmonton)

Where had you been living before that? (Scotland)

For how many years did you prepare meals? (2 years)

How far was it to your nearest store? (2 miles)

How often could a visit be made to the store? (Twice a year)

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? (Sugar, tea, syrup, flour, apples)

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? (I don't know)

In what quantities did you buy it? (20 pounds per year)

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? (25 cents)

How much did you use graham flour?

Whole wheat flour?

Was flour milled locally? (Yes)

How far away? (A mile)

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? (I don't know)

What other grain products did you use?

Cornmeal?

Other?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?

How did you grind it?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? Usually 100 lbs.
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.50.
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Cream.
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 20 lb.
At what price? About $0.70.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From cows.
Butter? Made at home. Eggs? Laid by hens.
What was the price of butter? $1.25. Eggs?
Did you pick eggs for winter? Yes. How?
Did you make butter? Yes. Cheese? Yes.
What kind of cheese? Whole cream.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? From our own.
How did you get fresh meat? We raised our own.
How often did you get fresh meat? All winter.
How did you preserve meat? Dried it in summer.
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.
If so, what year was it organized?
Did you use game? Yes. What kinds? Ducks & pheasants.
For how long?
What part did fish play in the family diet?
Has the fish fresh, cured, or canned?
Kinds? Salmon.

5. MEAT AND FISH

Did you use game? [Handwritten: Yes]

Did you kill fish in the river? [Handwritten: Yes]

Did you use canned or canned fish? [Handwritten: Yes]

Kind? [Handwritten: Salmon]

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homgrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We gradually used more canned goods but still think the meals are about the same only more variety - we have electricity & gas in the city

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

We went to town twice a year & never seemed to be out of necessities a box of Sulphur matches '25¢' & a yr a 15 gals of kerosene also lasted the year. We went to bed until the news didn't smoke & had little to read except the Montreal Family Herald which we purchased in 1895 & have been reading ever since. I am a pioneer when we came to our district, no school, no church, no post office, but in 1896 got school, post office 1895 & built church in 1903 - also held services in different homes & school house. My father purchased his groceries etc. from R D McNaughton in Moosomin which was 60 miles
